Mohsen, unfortunately I did not have any role in writing the Matlab versi=
on of NEAT and have never used it myself, so it is indeed possible that it =
differs from regular implementations of NEAT, or even has a bug.  It does a=
ppear that the max fitness graph is behaving strangely by jumping up and do=
wn.  One possibility is that the Matlab code does not implement elitism: mo=
st NEAT implementations keep the best individual of each species from one g=
eneration to the next, but perhaps Matlab NEAT is not doing that.

What I w=
ould do is try to track the best individual in the code to see what happens=
 during reproduction.  If it is not copied into the next generation, then y=
ou would know the problem.  On the other hand, if it is copied, yet for som=
e reason performs differently, then you would know there is a different, mo=
re serious kind of bug.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mohsen Davarynej=
ad <davarynejad@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
> 
> 
> Actually I played a bit with=
 the original Matlab implementation code of NEAT
> which I downloaded from
=
> here<http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/soft-view.php?SoftID=3D23> that
> includes t=
he XOR experiment. I only changed the fitness function from
> (4-individual=
_fitness)^2 to (81-individual_fitness)^2 (in xor_experiment
> function). I =
have attached the results I got (Regression-NEAT1.jpg). Should
> I consider=
 it as a bug, since I could not interpret the results, specially
> the fact=
 that the maximum fitness plot is not a monotonically increasing
> function=
.
> 
> 
> 
> The reason I did this experiment is because I wanted to see ho=
w good a
> standard NEAT can approximate a function. So I generated 81 trai=
ning samples
> spanning [-2 : 0.5 : 2] with an output between 0 and 1 (the =
function
> was [x*exp(-x^2
> - y^2) + .5]). I only replace the XOR training=
 data set with my training
> data set and changed the activation function f=
rom
> 1./(1+exp(-4.9*population(index_individual).nodegenes(3,4:number_node=
s))) to
> 1./(1+exp(-1*population(index_individual).nodegenes(3,4:number_no=
des))) and
> the fitness function as the one I mentioned above. Again I was=
 expecting a
> monotonically increasing function in maximum fitness plot
> =
(Regression-NEAT2.jpg), but surprisingly this was not the case. I realized
=
> that its maybe duo the fact that the species may die out. But the point i=
s
> that it never converge to an acceptable solution, even its not increasi=
ng,
> but seems like a decreasing function. I have attached the results I g=
ot
> after 1000 iterations.
> 
> 
> 
> I will appreciate if somebody could =
reflect on these results.
> 
> 
> 
> Thank you so much,
> 
> Mohsen.
